heading: 1 Study Premise
text: Body Advocacy Movement Study (Phase 1: 2021-2023) pilot study investigating feasibility, acceptability, preliminary efficacy eating disorder risk reduction intervention developed EMBARK lab 2020.existing, dissonance programs (.e. Body Project) target reductions thin-ideal internalization, fears related fatness weight gain may particularly salient cognitive target among current past eating disorder symptomatology (Levinson et al., 2014). effort mitigate risk ED onset relapse among high-risk young adults (.e. ED partial- full-remission /ongoing subthreshold ED symptoms), current project includes development initial evaluation novel, peer-led intervention focuses specifically fear fatness anti-fat bias (Body Advocacy Movement; BAM).project aims recruit 60 young adults (ages 18-26) – randomized standard dissonance intervention program (Body Project; N = 20) BAM (N = 40). objective examine degree BAM can reduce fear fatness weight gain along internalized anti-fat bias reduce risk ED symptom exacerbation promote ongoing ED recovery high-risk, young adult sample. evaluate feasibility acceptability BAM estimate effects intervention self-report behavioral measures fear weight gain fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. conduct initial effect size comparisons Body Project determine whether BAM shows potency specifically targeting fear fatness anti-fat bias.

heading: 1.1 Specific Aims
text: Aim 1: Examine acceptability feasibility BAM high-risk young adult sample. Acceptability: Acceptability assessed via attrition across 4-session intervention along qualitative feedback brief survey post-intervention. expect meet benchmarks high acceptability (average ratings > 4 [5] post-intervention survey; < 20% attrition). Feasibility: Feasibility benchmarked via intervention adherence (average competency > 8.0 0-10 scale) recruitment goals.Aim 2: Estimate effects intervention fear fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms. hypothesize BAM intervention result acute reductions (post-intervention) fatphobia anti-fat bias across self—report behavioral measures, outperforming Body Project targets related anti-fat bias, specifically.

heading: 2 Study Premise
text: Body Advocacy Movement (BAM) High Study (Phase 1: 2022-2023) pilot study investigating feasibility, acceptability, preliminary efficacy eating disorder risk reduction intervention within high school students developed EMBARK lab 2022.existing, dissonance programs (.e. Body Project) target reductions thin-ideal internalization, fears related fatness weight gain may particularly salient cognitive target among current past eating disorder symptomatology (Levinson et al. (2014)). Past studies demonstrated high school population (youth ages 14-18) especially susceptible development eating disorders like anorexia nervosa () bulimia nervosa (BN) ((kohnEatingDisordersChildren2001?)). effort mitigate risk ED onset minimize development EDs among late adolescents, current project includes development initial evaluation novel intervention focuses specifically fear fatness anti-fat bias (Body Advocacy Movement High Schools; BAM High).project aims recruit 30 high school students (ages 14-18) participate BAM High intervention. objective examine degree BAM can reduce fear fatness weight gain along internalized anti-fat bias reduce risk development ED symptoms late adolescent sample. evaluate feasibility acceptability BAM High estimate effects intervention self-report behavioral measures fear weight gain fatness, anti-fat bias, eating disorder symptoms.

heading: 3 Procedures
text: first wave study include recruitment 30 high school students (ages 14-18) take part intervention improve body image advocate body positivity. Participants complete four facilitator-lead, 1-hour sessions, complete series assessments baseline, post-intervention, conclusion final session 1-month follow-.

heading: 3.1 Recruitment
text: Recruitment sources include: (1) School administrators teachers (2) flyering area businesses (e.g. fitness centers, coffee shops) high school emailing services (3) online advertisement social media platforms (4) Outreach community-based organizations (5) Outreach ED providers community

heading: 4.1 The Body Advocacy Movement
text: BAM leverages dissonance exposure-based intervention strategies, adapting common exercises used promote body acceptance challenge sociocultural body ideals specifically target anti-fat bias internalized fatphobia. Participants BAM (1) Define anti-fat bias fatphobia explore constructs manifest personal beliefs interpersonal interactions, (2) Engage imaginal exposure exercises challenge fears related fatness weight gain (3) Reflect fears fatness align personal values, (4) Learn new ways challenge fear fatness internalized anti-fat bias (5) Discuss ways challenge anti-fat bias institutional societal level. Intervention content.

heading: 4.1.1 Session 1
text: Session 1 includes introductions, discussing identities clarifying terminology, exercise defining anti-fat bias fatphobia.

heading: 4.1.2 Session 2
text:
Within Session 2 participants asked complete imaginal exposure exercise several times week write recount ‘worst-case scenario’ might fear happen gained significant amount weight.##Session 3
Session 3 includes debriefing exposure homework identification ways one might uproot internalized fear fatness, along series role plays peer facilitators play role friend family member situation evokes anti-fat attitudes, participants practice challenging attitudes.

heading: 4.2 Session 4
text: Within session 4, participants also identify ways challenge anti-fat bias society commit engaging one activity coming week. exit exercise, write ‘response letter’ worst-case scenario.

heading: 4.3 Peer Facilitators
text: facilitators , minimum, graduate-level mental health providers. facilitator participate 8-hour training program, similar Stice et al. (2017). Facilitators role-play delivery entire intervention observe facilitators . Facilitators supervised Dr. Schaumberg.

heading: 4.4 Intervention Fidelity
text: Sessions audio recorded reviewed two members research staff. Audio recorded sessions rated fidelity competence. Research staff independently code randomly selected sample 50% sessions implementation fidelity facilitator competence using checklists assessing major exercises discussion topics session. component rated degree accurate presentation (10-point scale “adherence; section skipped” “Perfect; material section presented written”). Facilitator competence rated using 12 items assessing indicators competence (e.g., leaders express ideas clearly appropriate pace, leaders attempt allot equal speaking time members) 10-point scale.

Second recode questions missing codes change ‘NA’ ‘0’ answers labelled appropriately5-7. specifically calculate logic necessary specify exercise-related outcome variables, described key variables .8. cleans dataset removing erroneous variables longer needed.steps ar complete, additional weight suppression variables calculated added data R-scriptKey variables  Exercise Variables  ED100k_exercise_icb (exercise ever used behavior intentionally control weight shape?)

heading: 6.3 Eating Pathology Symptom Inventory
text: used 45-item Eating Pathology Symptom Inventory (EPSI; (Forbush et al., 2013)) assess eating disorder symptoms pre-intervention, post-intervention, 4-week follow-. EPSI validated clinical, college, community samples, 7-8 subscales various populations, 8-subscale version commonly-employed version measure (Coniglio et al., 2018). 8 subscales include: Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, Negative Attitudes toward Obesity, Muscle Building.ScoringEach item scored 5-point Likert-style scale (0 = Never; 4= Often) describe well item describes participant experiences. Scores derived summing responses across questions included subscale. eight subscales measure : Body Dissatisfaction, Binge Eating, Cognitive Restraint, Purging, Restricting, Excessive Exercise, Negative Attitudes toward Obesity, Muscle Building.Key VariablesAll variables reflect final scoring weighted subscale sum scores < 25% missing data.epsi_body_dissatisfaction_25epsi_binge_25 (binge eating)epsi_restraint_25epsi_purging_25epsi_restrict_25epsi_exercise_25 (excessive exercise)epsi_neg_attitude_25 (negative attidtude towards obesity)epsi_muscle_building_25

heading: 6.5 Child Food Security Survey Module (CFSSM)
text: U.S. Adult Food Security - Survey Module (US FSSM) (Carlson et al., 1999) developed USDA Food Nutrition Services 1995 assessing food security within households, specifically use Current Population Survey. US FSSM adapted administration children, creating Child FSSM (CFSSM), 9-item survey demonstrates sufficient reliability measuring food insecurity (connellFoodSecurityOlder2004?).ScoringRespondents answer 9 items either “lot”, “Sometimes”, “Never”. Responses “lot” “Sometimes” dichotomous affirmative “Never” remained negative. sum affirmative responses 9 questions raw score scale.Food security status assigned follows: | | - Raw score 0-1: Food secure | - Raw score 2-5: Food insecure without hunger | - Raw score 6+: Food insecure hunger | |Key Variables

heading: 6.6 Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7)
text: Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item (GAD-7) (Spitzer et al., 2006) seven-item instrument used measure assess severity generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). item asks individual rate severity symptoms past two weeks. Response options include “”, “several days”, “half days” “nearly every day”. GAD-7 widely-used well-validated measure anxiety screening (Sapra et al., 2020). GAD-7 scored unidimensional scale summing 7 items, cutoffs can also employed interpretation clinical severity: | | Minimal anxiety = 0-4 | Mild Anxiety = 5-9 | Moderate Anxiety = 10-14 | Severe Anxiety = 15-21. | |ScoringThe sum respondent’s answers used generate idea respondent’s anxiety level. score 10 points higher indicates probably anxiety disorder, 89% sensitivity 82% specificity GAD. also created dichotomized measure likely anxiety (cutoff score 10 greater), along clinical severity index (minimal, mild, moderate, severe).Key variablesgad_sum_25 (Sum GAD-7, 25% less items missing weighted N items completed)gad_cutoffs (GAD-7 anxiety severity cutoffs employed)gad_anx_disorder (GAD-7 probable anxiety disorder Yes/)

heading: 6.7 Goldfarb Fear of Fat Scale
text: Goldfarb Fear Fat Scale (GFFS) 10-item scale introduced 1985 diagnostic tool measure one’s fear fat can indicator development eating disorder (Goldfarb et al., 1985). used screening tool clinical non-clinical groups, GFFS strong test-retest reliability psychometric properties (Przybyta-Basista et al., 2022). addition, test also shown high validity populations without eating disorders (Goldfarb, 2010) original factor structure defined single-factor, Przybyta-Basista et al. (2022) also supported two-factor structure non-clinical sample: (1) fear weight gain (2) fear losing control eating/weight.ScoringGFFS uses 4-point scale 1 equal untrue 4 equal true. GFFS scored summing items create total score. measure also contains two subscales (fear weight gain (FOWG) loss control (LOC) can also summed.Key VariablesFor variables , _25 appendix reflects individuals <25% missing items scale included weighted sums based number items completedgffs_sum_25 (sum items)gffs_fowg_25 (sum fear weight gain subscale)gffs_loc_25 (sum loss control items)

text: Mini Menstrual Questionnaire, MMQ, tool EMBARK Lab created assess menstruating individuals’ menstrual history current menstrual status. measure assesses regularity individual’s menstrual cycles, form birth control () individual uses, pregnant breastfeeding, past gynecological procedures undergone ().

heading: 6.9 Scale of Subjective Social Status (SSSS)
text: MacArthur Scale Subjective Social Status - Youth Version measures perceived social status among adolescents 7th 12th grade (goodmanAdolescentsPerceptionsSocial2001?). measure includes two ladders: one assess perceived family status US American Society assess perceived personal status within one’s school community.Scoring two ladders 10 rungs participants can place . top rung represents people “best ” US American society (described money, highest amount schooling, jobs bring respect) first ladder people school highest status (described highest grades, standing, respect) second ladder. Higher scores (10 highest) represent higher perceived social status setting.Key Variables

heading: 6.10 Beck Depression Inventory (BDI)
text: Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) 21-item, self-report survey measures characteristic attitudes symptoms depression (beckInventoryMeasuringDepression1961?). Participants asked rank question, reflects symptom attitude related depression, scale 0 3, zero reflecting absence symptom attitude 3 reflecting severe experience symptom attitude. example, one question asks feelings failure options range “feel like failure.” “feel like complete failure person.”ScoringScoring completed summing totals 21 items. higher score represents higher symptomatology depression (Beck et al., 1988). Although Beck colleagues urge clinicians use clinical judgement assigning cut-scores, typically score 10 lower represents none minimal depression, 10-18 indicates moderate depression, 19-29 indicates moderate severe depression, scores 30 indicates severe depression (Beck et al., 1988).Key Variables

heading: 6.11 Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire (SATAQ)
text: Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire-4 (SATAQ) designed assess societal interpersonal aspects appearance ideals. SATAQ five validated factors: Internalization Thin/Low Body Fat, Internalization Muscular/Athletic, Pressures Family, Pressures Media, Pressures Peers. scale structure confirmed 3 independent geographically diverse samples women United States (East Coast N = 440, West Coast N = 304, North/Midwest N = 349). SATAQ-4 scale scores demonstrated excellent reliability good convergent validity measures body image, eating disturbance, self-esteem. measure also validated college males United States (N = 271); however, evidence underlying structure unique men. purposes current data, 5-factor structure employed scoring.ScoringFor SATAQ, total score generated based mean respondent’s answers. Additionally, subscale scores (internalization thinness/low body fat, internalization muscular/athletic. pressures - family, pressures - peers, pressures - media) also calculated.Key VariablesVariables _25 appendix indicate variables include 25% less missing datasataq_mean_25 (mean SATAQ)sataq_thin_ideal_25 (mean internalization thin ideal)sataq_athletic_ideal_25 (mean internalization athletic ideal)sataq_parental_pressure_25 (mean parental pressure)sataq_peer_pressure_25 (mean peer pressure)sataq_media_pressure_25 (mean media pressure)

heading: 6.12 Traditional Masculinity-Femininity Scale (TMFS)
text: Traditional Masculinity-Femininity Scale (TMFS) introduced 2016 assess self-ascribed masculinity femininity (Kachel et al., 2016). TMFS demonstrated high reliability sexes. Additionally, TMFS shows validity due ability reduce issues social desirability given self-assessment. TMFS uses 7-point likert scale 1 equal totally masculine 7 equal totally feminine. terms scoring, mean taken given answers average less 4 implying masculinity average greater 4 implying femininity.ScoringThe mean taken given answers average less 4 implying masculinity average greater 4 implying femininity.Key Variablestmfs_mean_25 (average scores response questions asking different situations one consider femininity masculinity. 25% less missing data)

heading: 6.13 Fat Stereotypes Questionnaire (FSQ)
text: Davison Birch (davisonPredictorsFatStereotypes2004?) developed Fat Stereotype Questionnaire (FSQ) assess fat stereotypes among 9 year old girls. scale asks participants think attributes happiness, intelligence, attractiveness, laziness, lot friends, goodness/badness relation fatness thinness.Scoring Participants respond prompts descriptors “thin” “fat” people subject. respond using four-point Likert scale, ranges “really disagree” “really agree,” produces 18 scores (9 “fat” subjects 9 “thin” subjects). Scoring completed calculating discrepancy scores (fat people attribute - thin people attribute) calculating mean 9 discrepancy scores. Scores 0 indicate participant strongly endorses attribute thin people, whereas scores 0 indicate participant strongly endorses attribute fat people. Importantly, calculating mean score, attributes need reverse coded order interpret values direction. internal consistency measure Davison Birch’s (2014) sample ɑ = 0.71.Key Variables

(lopez-guimeraPsychometricPropertiesPerception2012?) validated 11-item version POTS Spanish adolescents. measure contains two subscales: weight-related teasing competency-related teasing. subscales satisfactory level internal consistency. response--teasing also assessed asking participant experienced emotional distress due teasing experienced.ScoringThe teasing scale ranges “never” “always,” “always” occupying number five. upset scale also 5-point Likert scale “upset” “upset”. final teasing score generated generating sum score teasing items. separate score emotional distress calculated creating sum repsonse--teasing items.Key Variables

heading: 7.1 Weight Implicit Association Test (Weight IAT)
text: Weight-IAT task data housed (long-format) data set within study database, keys subject_id timepoint.Weight-IAT validated measure automatic, unconscious attitudes previously used evaluate implicit weight-related biases (Phelan et al., 2014) Weight-IAT compares accuracy , time required categorize images larger-bodied thinner people together positively- negatively-valanced words. Outcomes include reaction time percentage correct categorizations.

heading: 7.1.1 Scoring
text:
IAT scoring algorithm involves several steps, rigorous scoring procedure involving 12 specifications (Greenwald et al., 2003)Steps include:Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Using data Blocks 3,4,6, 7Eliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msEliminate trials latencies > 10,000 ms; eliminate subjects 10% trials latency less 300 msUse remaining trialsUse remaining trialsNo extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)extreme-value treatment (beyond Step 2)Compute mean correct latencies blockCompute mean correct latencies blockCompute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Compute one pooled SD trials blocks 3 & 6; another blocks 4 & 7Replace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msReplace error latency block mean (computed Step 5) + 600 msNo transformationNo transformationAverage resulting values four blocksAverage resulting values four blocksCompute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Compute two differences: B6 - B3 B7 - B4Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Divide difference associated pooled- trials SD Step 6Average two quotients Step 11Average two quotients Step 11R code used cleaning Weight-IAT data prior implementing scoring algorithm available - yet available.
R code completing scoring algorithm cleaned data available - yet avaialble

Critically, response option associated probability reward outcome (points) additional outcome (.e., images body parts larger bodies). response-outcome contingencies (e.g., option likely lead reward) switch throughout task, half time option likely lead reward also likely lead seeing large body images (Conflict Phase), half time highest reward option least likely lead seeing large body images (Congruent Phase) . Task Phases counterbalanced order allow initial task structure learning introduction Conflict Phase.trials, outcomes (image type, point win/loss) either 80%, 50%, 20% chance occurring. image type point win/loss probabilities independent one another. Code scoring Weight-AAT using Linear mixed Effects Model Approach available - yet availableWeight-AAT task data housed (long-format) data set within study database, keys subject_id timepoint.Linear Mixed Effects Model uses trial-wise outcomes (.e. modeling outcomes trials participant). Prior analysis, predictors outcomes scaled analysis including block, Phase (Conflict = -1, Congruent - 1), Trial (z-scored within block) regressed Total Points (scaled 0 1). heading: 10 Analytic Plan
text: Aim 1: Confirm feasibility acceptability fatphobia weight stigma intervention. confirm feasibility acceptability intervention structure content via () study attrition timepoints, (b) participant attendance 4 sessions, (c) completion rates study activities prior following sessions, (d) intervention adherence facilitator competence. assess intervention adherence facilitator competence, sessions audio recorded reviewed two members research staff using 12-item leader competence assessment. course study, expect study attrition <20%, attendance 4 sessions >80%, completion rates study activities >75%. Feasibility benchmarked via two primary outcomes: () expect high levels intervention adherence intervention, high interrater reliability average treatment fidelity facilitator competence ratings 8.0 10-point scale, (b) expect meet recruitment goals (N = 30).Aim 2: Estimating intervention effects. Reductions anti-fat bias assessed via changes self-report fatphobia anti-fat bias well shifts IAT AAT task performance baseline post-intervention baseline 4-week follow-. evaluate changes time singular group, use paired t-test assess intervention changed participants’ cognitions fatphobia weight stigma.Aim 3: Eating Disorder Prevention. Reductions eating disorder symptomology assessed via changes self-report eating disorder behaviors cognitions baseline post-intervention baseline 4-week follow-. specifically assess intervention affected participants identified demonstrating disordered eating (ED) baseline. evaluate changes time ED healthy group, use mixed effects modeling, estimating fixed effects Condition, Time, Time x Condition interaction, random intercept participant account baseline differences.
